coredata.dc:title: An improved procedure for the construction of ion-pair distribution functions within the Debye-Hückel framework
coredata.dc:creator: Cooper, I.L.
Harrison, J.A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A recently proposed scheme for the construction of physically realistic pair functions for the distribution of ions about a central reference ion within the framework of the Debye-Hückel model is assessed and extended to include the effects of different distances of closest approach for like and unlike ions within the screening cloud around the central ion. Improved values for the mean configurational energy per ion are predicted when compared to the results of Monte Carlo simulation studies.

Introduction We have shown recently [1 I that the traditional Debye-Mickel (DH) model [2] can be adapted so that the pair distribution function for identical ions (co-ions) remains non-negative at all separations from the central reference ion. This was achieved via the self-consistent determination of an effective hardsphere diameter .for co-ions within the constraint of a linear charge-potential relationship and with the preservation of overall charge neutrality. The present communication will demonstrate how the model can be improved and simplified, such that the predicted values of the mean configurational energy per ion become identical to those of the DH model itself. This procedure can then be extended, within the framework of a local density approximation, to account not only for the finite size of ions within the screening cloud around the central reference ion, but also for the different distances of'closest approach of like and unlike ions, thereby taking ion-ion repulsion effects between equivalent ions in the atmosphere into account. The results will be shown to yield considerable improvement over those arising from the DH model itself, with the restriction to ion concentrations which are sufficiently low that oscillations within the screening cloud do not occur [3]. The paper is structured as follows. Section 2 assesses 0 009-2614/85/$ 0330 © Elsevier Science Publishers B_V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) the model described in ref.
